channel.title: Help with indexBuilder
channel.description: Hey everyone, Need a bit of help with my code. I'm working on the indexBuilder class and have uploaded all of my code via file downloads[br][size=1]Posted at: November 01, 2006, 02:35:37 PM[/size][hr]the file to be indexed

item.title: Help with indexBuilder
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Typically, you’re forced to use the non-standard set style and therefore can’t use the java.util.Collections functions :\ Nor does it have a toArray method lol.

Oh well, what you could do is create another MiniHashMap…i don’t know about the efficiency of this, but meh:

	public String getMostFrequentWords(int arg0) {
		MiniHashMap<String, Integer> mapCount = new MiniHashMap<String, Integer>();
		
		int highestWordFrequency = 0;
		String mostFrequentWord = null;
		while(String s : map.keySet()){
		    int wordCount = 1 + (map.containsKey(s) ? map.get(s) : 0);
			map.put(s, initialWordCount);
			
			if(wordCount > highestWordFrequency) {
			    highestWordFrequency = wordCount;
			    mostFrequentWord = s;
			}
		}
		
		return mostFrequentWord;
	}

Didn’t test, but it should work. Also I don’t know what exactly you’d want to return, so i’ll leave it up to you now

Read full topic

item.title: Help with indexBuilder
item.dc:creator: @iwasinmoparseas101cl iwasinmoparseas101class
item.description:
@iwasinmoparseas101cl wrote:

no, what we are doing is reading in the file (the entire macbeth play), and storing every word in the hashmap. then we can call the the methods in the IndexBuilder class to get the most used word (and 2nd most, 3rd most, etc.), and we can also retrieve the lines that a word appears on.

Read full topic
